Question: 1. Subdivision/layout plan which shall be drawn on a scale of not less than _______
Explanation: Explanation: As per National Building Code, scale for Layout plan is specified as 1:500. In this plan, location of all proposed and existing roads, dimensions of plot along with building line, locations of sewer and drainage line etc. are mandatory.

Question: 2. The plan of the buildings and elevations and sections accompanying the notice
Option A: shall be drawn to a scale _____
Explanation: Explanation: This plan includes floor plans which shows the use or occupancy of all parts of the building. Hence this parts needs to be large enough for the Engineers to understand well. Therefore NBC have specified scale of 1:100.

Question: 3. A _____ line usually parallel to the plot boundaries and laid down in each case by the Authority, beyond which nothing can be constructed towards the site boundaries.
Explanation: Explanation: Building line or Set-back is provided to avoid traffic congestion in front of the building. Buildings like mall, multi-complexes, factories, etc. which attract large number of vehicles, should have be set-back a further distance apart from the building line. This line after this extra margin is called as Control Line.

Question: 4. The ratio of the total floor area inclusive of all the floors to the area of the plot on which building stands is known as _____
Explanation: Explanation: It is also known as the Floor Space Index (FSI) or Floor Area Ratio (FAR). The value of built-up area is determined by local authorities and it may be different for different areas for different buildings of the town. Floor area means built up area excluding area of walls.

Question: 5. The aggregate area of doors and windows shall not be less than _____ of the floor area of room.
Explanation: Explanation: As per IS code, if the area is less than the specified area, occupants of the building will not receive enough lighting and ventilation. The area of such openings excluding area of doors should be minimum 1/10  of the floor area for dry-hot climate and minimum 1/6 of the area for wet-hot climate.

Question: 6. The placing of various rooms or units of a structure in proper correlation of their functions and in due proximity with each other is known as _____
Explanation: Explanation: Grouping is the proper arrangement of rooms according to their functions leads to better planning of a building. It is observed that grouping leads to saving in unnecessary movements, proper correlation, easy control and overall economy.

Question: 7. The term ______ is used to mean the external views as seen from certain rooms of the building.
Explanation: Explanation: Prospect is dictated by the surrounding peculiarities of the site of the project. This can help us to conceal some unwanted views and reveal the beauty of the building.

Question: 8. The area on the earth which lies between the zones of cancer and Capricom is known as the _______
Explanation: Explanation: Topic zone lies between zone of cancer (i.e. 231/2  degree north latitude) and Capricom (i.e. 231/2  degree south latitude). The typical features of tropical countries are burning sun, fixed seasons and rainfall which is heavy, moderate and with storm.

Question: 9. Landscape architecture comes under in which principle of planning?
Explanation: Explanation: Aesthetic plays major role in the architectural landscaping. It includes the appearance of the building and overall beauty. Whereas function and form are both same which deals with the utility of the rooms according to their functions.

Question: 10. When building bye-laws came into force?
Explanation: Explanation: Building bye-laws came into force on April 1984. This local law was framed by the subordinate authority. Its specifications are designed to minimum safeguard to the workers during construction; to the health and comfort of users; and to provide enough safety to the public in general.

Question: 1. Burnings sun, fixed seasons and rainfall which is heavy, moderate and with storm are the typical features of _______
Explanation: Explanation: The area on earth which lies between the zone of cancer and Capricom is known as the tropics. Whole part of India is considered to be typically tropical climate.

Question: 2. The tropical climate which consists of heat waves hot winds and low humidity comes under which climatic conditions?
Explanation: Explanation: Hot-dry places are cool in winter. The maximum day temperature in summer will be about 27°C to 42°C and the night temperature will be moderate say about 15°C to 25°C.

Question: 3. Which city of Maharashtra experiences Hot-dry climatic conditions.
Explanation: Explanation: Ahmedabad, Nagpur and similar other places situated away from the coastal regions are the typical example of experiencing hot dry climate. These regions are famous for highest temperature records in India during summer season.

Question: 4. Which type of climate consists of high humidity throughout the year and even in the dry season with variations in day and night temperatures.
Explanation: Explanation: The temperature ranges in hot season and cold season or 25°C to 30°C and 10°C to 22°C respectively. Bombay which is situated near the sea is a typical example of experiencing hot wet or humid climate.

Question: 5. The data regarding temperature, moisture, timings of sunset and sunrise and direction of wind are collected and preserved by ____________
Option A: a) Bureau of Indian Standards, New Delhi
Option B: b) Meteorological Department of the Ministry of Commerce, Govt. of India
Option C: c) Indian Institute of Weather Forecasting and Research Centre
Explanation: Explanation: Meteorological Department of the Ministry of Commerce, Govt. of India works throughout the year and records every data possible. They predict the future climatic conditions by comparing the past records of 10 to 15 years. This department has recognised the following four seasons of the year: Cool-dry, Hot-dry season, General Rainy season, Season of the Retreating South-West Monsoon.

Question: 6. From the given climatic conditions which have its worst effects on the building structure in India.
Explanation: Explanation: Every year due to heavy rain huge destruction of building materials takes place. Mumbai itself invests more than Rs.10000 crore maintenance and repair of buildings.

Question: 7. Which building material have high Seismic resistance and flexibility of nailed joints.
Explanation: Explanation: As long has materials and workmanship are of good quality, timber structures can perform very well in an earthquake. A wooden frame is usually considered to have medium to low vulnerability towards earthquake.

Question: 8. Pyramids are the best example of ______
Explanation: Explanation: Triangle is the most stable geometric structure. Hence, the pyramids are very well designed and can sustain for long periods. Along with durability, these structures can withstand severe weather conditions like earthquake.

Question: 9. Which is the most important advanced technique of earthquake resistant design and construction?
Explanation: Explanation: Along with energy dissipation devices, Base Isolation technique is most advanced which isolates the structure by a series of bearing pads. This bearing pads absorbs maximum shocks develop due to seismic activity.

Question: 10. The temperature at the _______ is the highest and it is lowest at the ______
Explanation: Explanation: India is in the Tropics zone and hence there is a temperature gradient from equator to poles and depending upon the latitude of the locality, its temperature range can be decided.

Question: 1. _______ used to mean the regulation of admitting more or less sunshine in the room.
Explanation: Explanation: The meaning of aspect has now been given wider scope and it includes the arrangement of doors and windows in the external walls of buildings particularly of residential buildings, so as to fully enjoy the natural gifts of sunshine, Breeze, scenery, etc.

Question: 2. The term ______ is used to mean the link or access or movement between the various rooms and floors of building.
Explanation: Explanation: The proper provision of circulation makes the building comfortable and convenient. The circulation in a building is of two types- Horizontal circulation and Vertical circulation.

Question: 3. _________ is used to indicate the architectural effect produced by elevation in relation to width, height position of doors and windows, materials employed in the construction of external walls, etc.
Explanation: Explanation: The result of elegance is aesthetics and without the aesthetics sense, the elevation will be devoid of elegance. For creating elegant structures, it is necessary to understand clearly the principles of architectural design and composition.

Question: 4. The placing of various rooms or units of a structure in a proper correlation of their functions and in due proximity with each other is known as ________
Explanation: Explanation: Correct grouping grants the status of a balanced design. For instance, in a residential building, kitchen and dining room should be grouped close to each other. It is observed that grouping leads to saving in unnecessary movements proper correlation easy control and overall economy.

Question: 5. One of the important requirements of good planning is ______
Explanation: Explanation: Privacy offers special comfort to the occupants. It should not be confused as it is the total isolation and is desirable only in certain cases as study rooms, library, etc. Privacy is of two types- External privacy and Internal privacy.

Question: 6. The term _______ is used to refer the effect derived from space of a room that is its length, width and height.
Explanation: Explanation: Roominess is nothing but the feeling of spaciousness. The planning of room should be such that maximum benefit is obtained from the minimum dimensions of the room. For example rectangle shaped room looks more spacious than square shaped room of same area.

Question: 7. As a principle of planning, the term _______ is used to mean architectural hygiene.
Explanation: Explanation: Sanitation comprise of drainage system and water supply. It includes proper sanitation of waste water along with its treatment and supply to the major pipelines.

Question: 8. Due to improper ventilation, which gas gets stuck into house and develops dizziness to the occupants.
Explanation: Explanation: If the room is not properly ventilated, there will be excessive quantity of carbon dioxide in the air. The more the amount of carbon dioxide, the more difficult is the breathing. For comfortable working, the carbon dioxide content should be limited to about 0.6% by volume.

Question: 9. The proper and sufficient ventilation results in absence of _________
Explanation: Explanation: The difference of temperature between the outside air and the inside air tends to the deposition of moisture on the room surfaces. This is known as the condensation and it can be effectively controlled by the provision of suitable ventilation of the room.

Question: 10. The ________ is required to control dust and other impurities in the air.
Explanation: Explanation: Controlling dust and other impurities from coming into the building is the main cause of insisting proper ventilation in the commercial buildings. The ventilation is also required to suppress odours, smoke, concentration of bacteria, etc.

Question: 1. Construction of cavity walls as external walls to protect the building from outside heat or cold as the hollow space between two walls act as an________
Explanation: Explanation: Properly insulated building cuts down the cost of electric burning in summer as well as in winter. Cavity walls is one of the types of thermal insulation which consists of two walls with cavity in between them.

Question: 2. __________ in a building means the free passage of clean air in a building.
Explanation: Explanation: Ventilation is essential in every building. The main cause of insisting proper ventilation in the industrial buildings is to control dust and other impurities from entering into the building rooms.

Question: 3. Which gas leads to suffocation and dizziness to the occupants when increase in its quantity in the air.
Explanation: Explanation: If the room is not properly ventilated, there will be excessive quantity of carbon dioxide in the air. It is observed that breathing is difficult when the amount of carbon dioxide by volume is about 6% and a man loses consciousness when it reaches about 10% or so.

Question: 4. The termite, which are responsible for the destruction of wooden materials, are popularly known as _______
Explanation: Explanation: There are over 2300 species of termites but only about 4% of the termite spaces are responsible for the damage of the buildings. The termites live in a colony and they are very fast in eating wooden and other cellulosic materials as food.

Question: 5. The science which deals with the sound insulation in a building is known as _____
Explanation: Explanation: The terms sound insulation all soundproofing is used to indicate the reduction in the level of sound when it passes through a building component. Acoustics becomes very essential in some buildings like cinema hall, Auditorium,  Opera House, etc.

Question: 6. Fire extinguisher extinguishes the small fires in the house bye using _____
Explanation: Explanation: Standards of fire safety or fire extinguishers are specified in the Building Code should be provided with sufficient and quick fire exit. Fire extinguishers are one of the important building requirements which helps in extinguishing small fires.

Question: 7. The process in which the difference of temperature between the outside air and the inside air tends to the deposition of moisture on the room surfaces is known as ______
Explanation: Explanation: The temperature difference which leads to condensation can be effectively controlled by the provision of suitable ventilation of a room.

Question: 8. The treatment given to the roof of a building to prevent the roof from the leakage of water is known as _________
Explanation: Explanation: One of the basic requirements in case of all the buildings is that the structural should remain dry as far as possible. If this condition is not satisfied, it is likely that the building may become inhabitable and hence damp proofing or water proofing is required.

Question: 9. _________ is a flexible material which is commonly used for the damp proofing.
Explanation: Explanation: Due to its physical nature, hot bitumen remain flexible even after cooling and it is placed on the bedding of concrete or mortar. This material should be applied with the minimum thickness of 3 mm. Whereas Mastic Asphalt is a semi rigid material and it forms and excellent impervious layer for damp proofing.

Question: 10. Which one of the given below is a chemical insecticide for termite proofing.
Explanation: Explanation: Dieldrin is a chlorinated hydrocarbon. The application of this chemical serve as a chemical barrier between the building and the ground and this method has proved to be most effective method of termite proofing. Whereas, Rodenticide is used for killing rats.

Question: 1. The part of a building constructed below ground level is known as _________
Explanation: Explanation: Foundation is laid below the ground level and it is in direct contact with sub-strata and transmits all the loads to the sub-soil. The structure below the ground level is also known as Substructure or Foundation (excluding plinth).

Question: 2. The load of the structure distributed by the foundation is __________
Explanation: Explanation: The foundation is laid below the ground in a such a way that the load of structure is uniformly distributed to the ground to make the structure stable.

Question: 3. For loose soil, the formula used to find the minimum depth of foundation is given by _______
Explanation: Explanation: The depth of foundations can also be obtained by drawing the lines of angles 45 degree and 60 degree from the base of the foundation towards ground level. Hence to simplify the method, Rankine formula is used.

Question: 4. The foundation in which the loading on the soil remains practically the same after the construction of the building is known as _______
Explanation: Explanation: Grillage foundation or Floating foundation is so adjusted that the weight of the excavated earth is just equal to the total load of the building. In such case, the settlement is reduced to a minimum extent.

Question: 5. _________ method of increasing the bearing power of soil becomes very useful when the load coming on the soil is practically uniform.
Explanation: Explanation: Raft foundations are very useful in the soil which is of yielding nature that is soft clay or reclaimed soil. The raft is designed as an inverted RCC roof with uniformly distributed load of the soil pressure and supported by walls, beams and columns.

Question: 6. When the ground is sloping, _______ foundations are used to correct the levels of the sloping ground on which the building is to be constructed.
Explanation: Explanation: Stepped foundation is adopted when the construction becomes  uneconomical to provide foundations at the same level. In this, minimum depth of 800 mm should be provided at all the points.

Question: 7. Which type of foundation is used for the construction of building on black cotton soil.
Explanation: Explanation: Black cotton soil is a clay or loose type of soil and is considerably swells and shrinks by variation in moisture content. The variation in the volume of the soil is to the extent of 20 to 30% of the original volume. Hence, Raft Foundation or Mat Foundation plays important role in uniform distribution of the load of structure over black cotton soil.

Question: 8. ________ is applied to the process of laying down certain lines and marks on the ground before the excavation of foundation trenches.
Explanation: Explanation: The sitting out or Ground tracing is mainly done for two purposes- firstly, the excavation of foundation trenches can be started immediately after this process is completed and secondly, the lines and marks established by this process serve as a guide.

Question: 9. If the foundation of the structure is to be divided into two or more independent units, ________ are provided to take care of unequal settlement.
Explanation: Explanation: Slip joints are situated on the boundary of independent units and they help in localising the effect of unequal settlement in affected portion of the structure only.

Question: 10. A common footing provided for two or more columns is known as _________
Explanation: Explanation: Combined footing becomes useful when an exterior column is situated near the boundary line of the plot and it is not possible to project its footing symmetrically on both the sides.

Question: 1. The part of the building above the ground level and up to the floor level immediately above the ground is known as __________
Explanation: Explanation: Plinth is therefore defined as the portion of the structure between the surface of the surrounding ground and surface of the floor, immediately above the ground. Plinth is an important component of building which prevents crawling animals, water and other insects from coming inside the building.

Question: 2. The built up area measured and the plinth level is known as __________
Explanation: Explanation: Plinth area is nothing but the build-up covered area measured at the floor level.

Question: 3. What should be the average height of plinth.
Explanation: Explanation: Generally the plinth level is provided at about 300 to 400 mm above finished ground level. It is suggested that plinth level should be decided by considering the top level of the ground and hence considering the level.

Question: 4. In a market area, the plinth area should not exceed ____ of the area of site.
Explanation: Explanation: As per regulations, the plinth area should not exceed 75% of the area of commercial sites, provided sufficient off-street parking facilities for loading and unloading of vehicles are provided on the same plot as the building.

Question: 5. The ______ provides support to the occupants, furniture, fixtures and equipments of a building.
Explanation: Explanation: Different floors divide the building in two different levels to provide more accommodation on a given plot of land. The floor of a building immediately above the ground is known as ground floor.

Question: 6. _________ is known as Substructure of the building.
Explanation: Explanation: Superstructure is the part of the building constructed about the plinth level. Foundation, plinth, basement, ground level, etc. comes under Superstructure.

Question: 7. The height of the Plinth should not be less than ____
Explanation: Explanation: According to Indian Standards, the minimum height for the Plinth is 45 cm. The height of the plinth depends upon architectural elevation, ground level, highest flood level, etc.

Question: 8. The portion below the plinth level is known as ______
Explanation: Explanation: Substructure or foundation is the lower portion of the building which lies below the plinth level. Substructure transmits the loads of the superstructure to the supporting soil.

Question: 9. Foundations are more susceptible to ______
Explanation: Explanation: Settlements is most commonly seen in foundation which are within the permissible limits, without causing cracks in the superstructure and soil does not fail in shear.

Question: 10. The word Plinth is derived from _____
Explanation: Explanation: In architecture, a Plinth ( from Greek plinthos, “brick”) is the base or platform upon which a column, pedestal, statue, monument or structure rests.

Question: 1. _______ is the part of building constructed above the plinth level.
Explanation: Explanation: Superstructure is constructed of above the plinth level which consists of RCC walls and columns, upper floors, sills, Lintels, etc. Whereas, substructure is a part of building constructed below the plinth level which consists of foundation plinth, etc.

Question: 2. In order to secure superstructure from earthquake, _________ technique is most preferred and used worldwide.
Explanation: Explanation: Base Isolation technique separates the building from the building foundation by wearing pads. It consists of lead rubber bearing or spherical sliding isolation system. In case of an earthquake, fix base building deform and damaged, whereas base isolated building rocks back and forth like a boat and reduce the shock by 60%.

Question: 3. In old times, the construction of superstructure was done by using _________ building material.
Explanation: Explanation: Timber floor consists of Plank of wood with 25 mm thickness which is supported by joist with size of 50 mm_75 mm to 100 mm. Timber was most preferred building material as compared to bamboo as Timber was cheap and easily available.

Question: 4. __________ wall is constructed in order to support load other than its own.
Explanation: Explanation: Load bearing walls support all loads before transferring them to the foundation the wall thickness is not money not less than one break or 215 mm. This wall also uses reinforcement Steel bars to strengthen its position.

Question: 5. In architecture, _________ refers to such super-structural element that also has certain proportional and decorative features.
Explanation: Explanation: Early columns were constructed of stone, some out of a single piece of stone, usually by turning on a lathe-like apparatus. Single piece columns are among the heaviest stones used in architecture. Modern columns are constructed out of Steel, precast concrete, or brick.

Question: 6. ________ are structural members design to carry and transfer transverse loads across space to support elements.
Explanation: Explanation: A beam is a structural element that is capable of withstanding load primarily by resisting bending. The bending force introduced into the material of the bean as a result of external loads, own weight and external reactions to these loads is called a bending moment.

Question: 7. In architecture, a _________ is generally the lower horizontal surface of a room, and/or the supporting structure underneath it.
Explanation: Explanation: A floor typically consists of a support structure called a sub-floor on the top of which is laid a floor covering to provide a working surface. The floor is actually constructed above the plinth.

Question: 8. ______ is the top most part of building which provides covering to the entire assembly and the occupants.
Explanation: Explanation: Roof is one of the most important building structures which provides safety and protect occupants from sun light, storms and rain. Basic types of a room designs are Flat roof, Shed roof, Gable roof, Hip roof, etc.

Question: 9. __________ is special material used to make sure that no moisture leaks in those areas of a roof that are particularly vulnerable to penetration.
Explanation: Explanation: Flashing is a strip of metal used to stop water penetrating the junction of a roof with another surface. Areas where flashing is commonly used: where roofs meet walls, wherever the roof is pierced by a Chimney, skylight, air or plumbing vent.

Question: 10. ________ is the structural method to maintain the favourable room temperature in every season of the year.
Explanation: Explanation: Because hot air rises,  roof lose more heat than walls and does require greater degree of insulation. There is a multitude of different locations for the insulation in a roof such as resting above ceiling, attached between rafters, between substrate and roofing, etc.

Question: 1. A square pit, know as _________ with side as about 1.50 m, is excavated upto a depth at which sufficiently hard soil is available.
Explanation: Explanation: Using Trail pits or Test pits, various Tata of the soil can be inspected, studied and classified accordingly. This method is useful when hard soil is available within a maximum depth of 1.50 metre.

Question: 2. _________ consists of driving either a hollow tube or a steel rod or an iron rod into the ground.
Explanation: Explanation: In Probing, a hollow tube of diameter 35 mm to 50 mm is taken. The tube is driven into the ground 300 mm or so at a time. It is then withdrawn and the material caught in the slit is inspected.

Question: 3. The ____________ is the term used to denote a method in which case is driven into the ground and the material inside the casing is washed out and brought to the surface for inspection.
Explanation: Explanation: The process of wash boring consists in driving an inner tube of diameter 25 mm to 50 mm, inside an outer tube of diameter 100 mm to 150 mm. Whereas, percussion boring and rotary drilling are the types of Deep boring.

Question: 5. The method in which 4 electrons are driven in the ground at equal distance apart and in a straight line upto a depth which the ground distance is to be measured.
Explanation: Explanation: This method is based on the principle that each soil has different electrical resistivity, depending upon its water content, compaction and composition. For instance, the saturated soil will have lower electrical resistivity as compared to the loose dry gravel or solid rock.

Question: 6. The number of blows required to drive the penetrometer into the ground through a distance of 300 mm is measured which is known as _____________ of the soil.
Explanation: Explanation: The bearing capacity and the other engineering properties of certain types of soil are they known by referring to the curves correlating Standard Penetration Resistance or SPT and the corresponding characteristics of soil. The values of SPT of soil and different depths are determined.

Question: 7. The resistance of the soil with depth is measured by means of a tool known as the _______
Explanation: Explanation: The penetrometer is used under static or dynamic loading which may consist of a sampling spoon, a cone or tool of other shape. The penetrometer is driven in the ground with the help of blows from a 650 N weight falling from a height of 750 mm.

Question: 9. The shock waves so produced travel down in the sub soil strata and get reflected after striking a hard rock surface below and recorded by the instrument known as _____
Explanation: Explanation: A number of geophones are arrange along a line. Some of the waves, known as direct or primary waves, are picked first buy Geophones. The Other waves which travel down through the soil get reflected after striking a hard rock surface below.

Question: 10. What is average depth of a Test pit?
Explanation: Explanation: Test Pit is excavated up to a depth about 1.50 m at which sufficiently hard soil is available. The various data of soil can be inspected, studied and classified accordingly. This method is useful when hard soil is available within a maximum depth of 1.50 m.

Question: 1. _________ is used to indicate the maximum load per unit area which the soil will resist safely without displacement.
Explanation: Explanation: The Load of the structure is ultimately coming on the soil and hence it is of utmost importance to know the strength and behaviour of the soil. Dividing the ultimate bearing power of soil by a factor of safety, the safe bearing capacity of soil is obtained.

Question: 2. The term _________ on soil is used to indicate the maximum pressure which can be exerted on soil while taking into account shear failure, settlement and the ability of structure to resist settlement.
Explanation: Explanation: The value of Allowable Bearing Pressure on soil depends on the nature of ground and the type of building. The maximum safe bearing capacity of soil is generally more than the allowable bearing pressure on soil.

Question: 3. The maximum differential settlement should not exceed _____ mm in case of foundation on sandy soil.
Explanation: Explanation: The total amount of settlement should be generally limited between 40 mm and 100 mm. The term differential settlement indicates the relative settlement of the adjacent portion of the structure.

Question: 4. The maximum differential settlement should not exceed ____ mm in case of foundation on clayey soil.
Explanation: Explanation: For ordinary frame structures of concrete, the permissible angular distortion is 1/500 i.e. one horizontal to 500 vertical and the desirable value is 1/1000 i.e. one horizontal to 1000 vertical. The term angular distortion is used to indicate the deformation of the structure in a vertical plane.

Question: 5. The maximum safe bearing capacity of hard rocks with defects and lamination such as granite, diorite and trap is _____ kN/m2.
Explanation: Explanation: The term maximum safe bearing capacity of soil is used to indicate the maximum pressure that is soil can be here without any risk of shear failure only, irrespective of any settlement that may occur.

Question: 6. The maximum safe bearing capacity of very soft, wet, pasty or muddy clay is ____ kN/m2.
Explanation: Explanation: As the given soil is very soft, wet, muddy clay, the soil possess very least minimum safe bearing capacity. This is because, this soil possess very less intermolecular attraction between the molecules hence it has low bearing capacity.

Question: 7. In case of non-cohesive soils such as sand and gravel, ___% reduction in allowable bearing capacity of the soil should be applied, if the water table is situated below or near the bearing surface of the soil.
Explanation: Explanation: However, if water table is situated below the bearing surface of the soil at a depth equal to the width of the foundation trench, no such reduction should be applied. But in this case, 50% reduction is applied. For intermediate depths of the water table, the proportion and percentage reduction should be applied.

Question: 8. Identify the method given below for the determination of the bearing power of soil.
Explanation: Explanation: Plate load test method is one of the methods of determination of bearing power of soil. Plate load test method is the improved point method and it is widely used for determination of the bearing capacity. Other methods for determination are: method of loading, method of dropping a weight, analytical methods and Presumptive method.

Question: 9. In which method, a square steel plate is used to determine the bearing power of soil.
Explanation: Explanation: In method of loading, a square steel plate is used whose size depends on practical conditions and it generally varies from 3000 mm2 to 7500 mm2. The plate should have sufficient thickness to with stand the maximum bending stresses due to probable loading.

Question: 10. The bearing capacity of soil is calculated in ______ units.
Explanation: Explanation: The bearing capacity of soil is calculated as the maximum load divided by the total area of steel plate i.e. Bearing Capacity = max. Load ÷ area of steel plate and the unit is N/m2 or kN/m2.

Question: 1. For determining the bearing capacity of soil, in method of loading the size for a square steel plate used is about ________
Explanation: Explanation: In method of loading comma the size of square steel plate generally variance from 3000 mm2 to 7500 mm2. The plates should have sufficient thickness to with stand the maximum bending stresses due to probable loading. But in no case, it should be less than 25 mm.

Question: 2. In method of loading, which material is used for loading.
Explanation: Explanation: The number of banks full of sand or arrange on the rolled Steel section. The sand bag is on the platform till the settlement of the ground ceases or stops. The loading should be applied without shock or impact at the centre.

Question: 3. The bearing capacity of sandy soil and gravelly soils is affected to the extent of _____% by the presence of water table.
Explanation: Explanation: If the water table is above the foundation level, the water should be pumped out before placing the steel plate. If water is made with at a depth of one metre below the level of the foundation level, the load test should be carried out at that level.

Question: 4. Due to the adjustment of soil particles under the action of loading, there is some settlement at zero loading, this is known as the ___________
Explanation: Explanation: Zero correction is obtained from the load settlement curve. The zero correction should be deducted from the observed settlements to get the actual settlements.

Question: 5. The loading to the test plate is applied with the help of ______
Explanation: Explanation: In plate load test, the hydraulic Jack is preferably provided with the remote control pumping unit. The reaction of the hydraulic jack is borne either by the gravity loading platform method or by the reaction truss method.

Question: 6. In analytical methods, which soil parameters used to determine the ultimate bearing capacity of soil.
Explanation: Explanation: Angle of internal friction and Cohesion are the soil parameters which are used in analytical method to determine the ultimate bearing capacity of soil. The samples, preferably of undisturbed soil, are collected from the bore holes or test pits and various test are then carried out in the soil testing laboratory for the purpose of analytical analysis of the soil.

Question: 7. In Penetration test, the formula obtained for the safe bearing capacity of soil per unit area is given by:
Explanation: Explanation: Safe bearing capacity of soil per unit area = R÷{A_F} where R is equals to ultimate resistance of soil, A = 2 cross sectional area of the substance, F equals two factor of safety. The results obtained by this method are approximate and hence this method is used for minor engineering structures.

Question: 10. Which method for determining the bearing power of soil is most preferred among the given below:
Explanation: Explanation: Plate load test is the improved refined method and it is widely used for determining the bearing capacity of soil for important civil engineering structures. This method can be carried out in two ways: gravity loading platform method and reaction Truss method.

Question: 1. Stone columns are invariably used in which soil.
Explanation: Explanation: It is normally used in soft inorganic soils. Stone columns are essentially a method of soil reinforcement in which soft cohesive soil is replaced at discrete points by compacted stone or crushed rock in pre bored vertical hole to form columns or files within the soil.

Question: 2. The construction of which piles proves to be very useful in case of sandy soil or soft.
Explanation: Explanation: These piles are formed by making holes in the ground and then filling the holes by sand. If sand is kept confined, it possesses great crushing strength and becomes incompressible.

Question: 3. The movement of soil under the action of load can be prevented by confining the ground by use of _________
Explanation: Explanation: When the sheet piles are used in such ground, it will result in the increase of bearing power of soil. The wooden sheet piles are commonly used for the temporary work such as cofferdams. They usually consists of wooden boards 80 mm to 150 mm thick, 200 mm to 300 mm wide and 2 metres to 4 metres long.

Question: 10. The commercial method which combines the effect of vibration with jetting is known as _______
Explanation: Explanation: Vibroflotation is very useful especially when the foundation is required to support heavy loads spread over a great area. In this method, a heavy cylinder known as Vibroflot is inserted in the ground while the cylinder vibrates due to a Rotary eccentric weight.

Question: 1. A spread is given under the base of a wall or common is known as ________
Explanation: Explanation: Such spread is known as footing and the foundation is known as spread footing. Footing which contains steps or off sets and it is also referred to as the step footing. If the wall rest directly on foundation concrete without any step, it is known as the simple footing.

Question: 2. What is the value of angle of response for clay(dry) soil.
Explanation: Explanation: The depth of footing should also be such that the rate of angle of spread of the load from the wall base to the outer edge of ground bearing does not exceed the permissible value.

Question: 6. Which Foundation is used when the wall carries light loads or when the safe bearing pressure is very high.
Explanation: Explanation: In that case, a simple strip footing is provided. The wall directly rest on the concrete base, and no masonry offset are provided since spread is not required.

Question: 1. ________ foundation is provided for heavily loaded Timber column or masonry wall.
Explanation: Explanation: Timber Grillage Foundation uses Timber planks and Timber beams in the place of Steel joists. This Foundation is specially useful in waterlogged areas where the bearing power of soil is very low.

Question: 2. In case of waterlogged area, the loading on the soil is limited to ____ KN/m2.
Explanation: Explanation: Water logged areas have very low bearing capacity of soil. Hands to overcome this we cannot use steel beams which may get corroded due to subsoil water therefore Timber grillage Foundation is preferred.

Question: 4. A _________ foundation is a special type of isolated footing, generally provided for heavy loaded steel structure specially in those location where bearing of soil is poor.
Explanation: Explanation: Grillage Foundation is very useful where bearing of soil is poor. The depth of foundation is limited from 1 m to 1.5 m. The load of column is distributed or spread to a very large area by means of layers of joists.

Question: 5. _______ is the method of increasing the bearing power of soil when load coming on the soil is practically uniform.
Explanation: Explanation: The raft is design as an inverted RCC roof with uniformly distributed load of soil pressure and supported by walls, beams and columns. This method consists of providing and RCC slab of suitable thickness and with necessary reinforcement with helps in increasing the bearing power of soil.

Question: 7. _______ consist of constructing the inverted arches between the piers.
Explanation: Explanation: The inverted arch should be set in cement mortar. The rise of the inverted arch is about 1/5th to 1/10th of the span and the inverted arch is invariably built in half brick rings.

Question: 8. _________ foundation is suitable for the structures such as bridges, reservoirs, supports for drainage lines, tanks, etc.
Explanation: Explanation: Inverted arch foundation is a method of spreading the weight over a large area is not common for the construction of foundations of buildings. Hence this method is applicable for the structures of large projects like bridges.

Question: 9. The ________ foundations are useful for public buildings, office buildings, School buildings, residential quarters, etc.
Explanation: Explanation: Raft foundation is the method of increasing the bearing power of soil becomes useful especially when there is a large number of openings on ground floor in a structure.

Question: 1. The formula- d=a_√(3q)/m is used to calculate _________
Option C: c) Depth of concrete bed block
Explanation: Explanation: The depth of concrete bed block depends upon the type of concrete, the projection of block and the soil bearing pressure. It is found on the basis of the bending moment imposed on it, and on the basis of safe modulus of rupture. Here,  d = depth of concrete block in metre, a = projection beyond the masonry face in centimetres, m = safe modulus of rupture of concrete mix, q = net soil bearing pressure.

Question: 2. If the wall or column under construction is near some other property, it will not be possible to spread the footing to both the sides of War or column. In search case which footing is used?
Explanation: Explanation: Normally, the footing are so designed and proportion that the centre of gravity of the superimposed load coincides with the CG of the base area, so that the footing is subjected to concentric loading, resulting in uniform bearing pressure. However, it may not be possible to do so and hence eccentric loading footings are applied.

Question: 8.  Which type of footing is applicable when the wall carries light loads or when the safe bearing pressure is very high?
Explanation: Explanation: In this case, the width of the footing would be very low. In this type of footing, the wall directly rests on the concrete base and no masonry offset are provided since spread is not required.

Question: 9. The shape of combined footing is mostly ______
Explanation: Explanation: The shape of the combined footing should be so selected that the centres of gravity of the column loads of soil reaction remains in the same vertical line. Usually a rectangular or a trapezoidal shape is selected.

Question: 10. A spread footing for a single column is known as the _____
Explanation: Explanation: A spread footing for a single column is either known as the isolated footing or pad footing. The base area of such a footing is given by A = P/q where P is the total load transmitted by the column, including that of the footing and q is the safe bearing pressure for the soil.

Question: 1. If the foundation of the structure is to be divided into two or more independent units, the _______ may be provided to take care of unequal settlement.
Explanation: Explanation: Slip joints are situated on the boundary of the independent units and they help in localising the effect of unequal settlement in affected portion of the structure only.

Question: 2. Which type of foundation should be adopted in a clayey or lose type of soil which considerably swells and shrinks by variation in the moisture content.
Explanation: Explanation: In case of clay or loose type of soil, Raft foundation is very helpful in increasing the bearing power of soil which becomes very useful when load coming on the soil is practically uniform.

Question: 3. Which types of foundation should be adopted when the ground is sloping and it is  economical to provide Foundation at the same level.
Explanation: Explanation: In such case, Stepped foundation is used to correct levels of the sloping ground on which the building is to be constructed and taken and a longitudinal section is prepared accordingly.

Question: 4. For heavy structures with uneven loading, the _______ should be adopted for the foundations.
Explanation: Explanation: Pile foundations are most appropriate when the loading of the structure is uneven. Piles are driven deep into the ground up to the hard Strata which helps to distribute the load evenly.

Question: 5. The cavities or old Wells occur during excavation of the foundation trenches are filled with ____
Explanation: Explanation: To make the foundation safe, such cavities or wells are need to be filled to avoid uneven settlement in future. If the cavity is small, it is filled with concrete. But if the cavity is large enough to make the feeling of concrete expensive, a suitable arch should be provided.

Question: 6. In case of soft soil, a line is drawn from the edge of bottom of old footing at an angle of ______ with the horizontal.
Explanation: Explanation: The horizontal spacing between two footing in case of average soil is adjusted by keeping the angle of inclination is 45°. The horizontal spacing of to footing its adjusted in such a way that the edge of bottom of new footing is not intersected by this line.

Question: 7. _______ indicates the dead load or weight of the machine for which Foundation is to be provided.
Explanation: Explanation: The static load is constant for a particular machine and it plays minor role in the design of a machine Foundation. The foundation area should be sufficient to take up this load.

Question: 8. In case of kinetic load, it is desirable to provide ______ at the top as well as and the bottom of the foundation block.
Explanation: Explanation: Reinforcement is provided even though the design considerations do not demand such reinforcements. The amount of reinforcement will depend on the type of machine.

Question: 9.To minimise the transmission of _______ the machine Foundation should be isolated from the adjoining parts of the building.
Explanation: Explanation: The foundations should be insulated from the vibrating machinery because it may cause settlements on sands and gravels. The various methods adopted for this purpose such as by filling in sand or saw dust between the foundation block and the side soil.

Question: 1. _______ occurs due to various reasons such as unequal distribution of load on the foundations, varying bearing power of the sub soil, eccentricity of the load, etc.
Option A: a) Unequal settlement of the sub-soil
Option B: b) Unequal settlement of the masonry
Option C: c) Horizontal movement of the earth
Option D: d) Withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil
Explanation: Explanation: Due to unequal settlement of the sub-soil, the cracks are formed in the buildings, which in future, leads to serious defects. To prevent such failure, the foundations should rest on the rock or hard murum.

Question: 2. The motor used as the binding material in the masonry construction shrinks and gets compressed when loaded excessively before it has fully set which leads to the __________
Option A: a) Unequal settlement of the sub-soil
Option B: b) Lateral pressure on the superstructure
Option C: c) Unequal settlement of the masonry
Explanation: Explanation: To avoid such Unequal settlement of the masonry, the mortar to be used in the masonry should be stiff and in line with the workability desired. The masonry work should be raised evenly.

Question: 3. _______ occurs at places where there is considerable variation in the height of water table.
Option A: a) Transpiration of trees and shrubs
Option D: d) Withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil
Explanation: Explanation: When withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil takes place i.e. water table falls, the soil particles loses Cohesion and hence, there is a shrinkage of soil, resulting in the cracks to the buildings.

Question: 4. Due to ______________ the thrust of a Pitched roof or arch action or wind action on the superstructure causes wall to overturn.
Option A: a) Horizontal movement of the earth
Option B: b) Lateral pressure on the superstructure
Option C: c) Unequal settlement of the sub-soil
Explanation: Explanation: The remedial measures to prevent lateral pressure on the  superstructure would be to provide a sufficient wide base and to design the foundations for the worst conditions.

Question: 5. Due to ______________ very soft soil is liable to give way under the action of load, especially at places such as sloping ground, riverbank, etc.
Option B: b) Lateral pressure on the superstructure
Option C: c) Transpiration of the trees and shrubs
Explanation: Explanation: In case of horizontal movement of the earth, it is desirable to construct the retaining walls to drive sheet piles to prevent the escape of the earth.

Question: 6. Due to the ____________ the roots of trees planted near a building may extend upto the foundation level and may absorb the moisture.
Option A: a) Withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil
Option B: b) Transpiration of the trees and shrubs
Option D: d) Unequal settlement of the soil
Explanation: Explanation: The effect of transpiration of trees and shrubs is seen in the form of a depression on the ground and it may lead to cracks in the buildings. The remedial measures such as the foundation should be taken sufficiently deep in case to avoid such effect.

Question: 7. To avoid __________ the foundations should be taken beyond the depth up to which rain water can not reach.
Option A: a) Unequal settlement of the soil
Option B: b) Horizontal movement of the earth
Option D: d) Withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil
Explanation: Explanation: Atmospheric action results in heavy rains or considerable variations in temperature or Frost action may damage the foundations. Hence the foundations are made at sufficient depth up to which rainwater cannot come in contact with it.

Question: 8. ________ results rain water carrying certain Chemicals and salt which reacts with the material used for the foundation work and turn them into powder.
Option B: b) Unequal settlement of the soil
Option C: c) Lateral pressure on the superstructure
Option D: d) Transpiration of trees and shrubs
Explanation: Explanation: The rain and son are the main atmospheric agents to seriously affect the foundation of a building. The rain may carry certain Chemicals and salts obtained from sewage, animal dung, etc. which reacts with the foundation and leads to its destruction.

Question: 9. In case of ________ it is seen that the allowable bearing pressure on the soil is not exceeded, even under the worst conditions.
Option A: a) Withdrawal of moisture from the sub-soil
Option B: b) Transpiration of trees and shrubs
Option C: c) Unequal settlement of the sub-soil
Explanation: Explanation: Such preventive measures are adopted in case of unequal settlement of the subsoil which leads to formation of cracks in the buildings, which in future, leads to serious defect.

Question: 10. The proper watering or curing for a period of at least 10 days should be done to the missionary work in case of ________
Option A: a) Horizontal movement of the earth
Option B: b) Unequal settlement of the masonry
Option C: c) Unequal settlement of the sub-soil
Option D: d) Lateral pressure on the superstructure
Explanation: Explanation: Proper watering or curing is done to ensure the development of adequate strength of mortar joints. In this case, the masonry work should be raised evenly.

Question: 1. _________ is defined as the main plank which remains in contact with sides of Trench.
Explanation: Explanation: The term Sheathing is used to indicate vertical members of timber in which directly resist pressure from the side of a Trench.

Question: 7. The __________ arrangement of preventing the sleep of earth in foundation trenches is used when the excavation is to be carried out in moderately firm ground.
Explanation: Explanation: In case of moderately firm ground, Stay bracing is adopted when the depth of excavation does not exceed 2 metres. In this, the vertical sheets of piling boards are placed opposite each other against the wall of the trench.

Question: 8. The _______ arrangement of preventing the slip of earth in the foundation trenches is adopted when large area is to be excavated for a depth greater than 10 meters.
Explanation: Explanation: Sheet piling is used when large area is to be excavated for depth greater than 10 meters, soil to be excavated is soft or loose, width of the trench is also large and the subsoil water is present.

Question: 9. In _______ arrangement, the vertical sheets are placed nearer or sometimes, touching each other.
Explanation: Explanation: The Box sheeting arrangement is adopted for loose soil. In this, the sheets are kept in position by longitudinal rows of wales, usually 2 in numbers and then, the Struts are provided across the wales.

Question: 10. The _______ method is similar to box sheeting except that the work is carried out in stages and at each stage, and offset is provided.
Explanation: Explanation: For deep trenches up to about 10 metres in soft ground, the vertical sheeting is adopted. In this for each stage, vertical sheets, horizontal wales, Struts and braces are provided as usual.

Question: 1. Which the given method is used for dewatering of the foundation trenches.
Explanation: Explanation: A Well Point is a pipe about 1 m long and diameter is about 40 mm to 50 mm. The whole system comprise of a Riser, swinger arm, header and together work as a well point system.

Question: 6. In case of releasing artesian pressure, which precaution should be taken when the system of well points is adopted.
Explanation: Explanation: Blowing action is adopted for release of artesian pressure. At some places, the artesian conditions exists at a certain death from the ground level. If the foundation trench reaches that depth, its bottom is likely to be blown off due to hydrostatic pressure.

Question: 7. Which precautions to be taken in case of multistage system to achieve stability of the side slope.
Explanation: Explanation: In case of multistage system of well points, the deep well pumps should be used when the instability of the side slopes is expected. As deep well pumps are expensive, they are adopted on important works.

Question: 8. The organic Chemicals include epoxy resin, polyester resin and other resins are used in which method of dewatering of the foundation trenches.
Explanation: Explanation: In 1925, H.J. Joosten, a Dutch mining engineer, adopted for the first time the chemical grouting. He used concentrated solution of sodium silicate and calcium chloride as electrolyte.

Question: 9. From given below, which method for the dewatering of foundation trenches is portable and can be easily moved when required.
Explanation: Explanation: In pumping method, the pumps are installed along the foundation trenches at a suitable points. The water gaining access to the trenches is pumped out. These pumps are portable so that it can be easily moved as and when required.

Question: 10. Identify the type of Well Point System which can suck water up to 5 meters.
Explanation: Explanation: The practical limit upto which the water can be lifted by a suction pump is about 5 meters or so. Hence, the depth of excavation is not to exceed 5 metres in single stage system well point is adopted.

Question: 6. In which method a refrigeration plant of required capacity is need to be installed near the site of work.
Explanation: Explanation: The principle of ground freezing process is the use of refrigeration to convert in-situ pore water to Ice. Hence, refrigeration plant of required capacity is installed near the site of work to perform the process of refrigeration.

Question: 7. ________ process consists of making a number of holes in the ground and then filling these holes by the cement grout under pressure.
Explanation: Explanation: In cement grouting method, the cement grout, which is a mixture of sand, cement and water is used. The term grouting is used to indicate a process of injecting the cementing materials into the cracks.

Question: 8. The organic Chemicals include epoxy resin, polyester resin and other resins are used in which method of dewatering of the foundation trenches.
Explanation: Explanation: In 1925, H.J. Joosten, a Dutch mining engineer, adopted for the first time the chemical grouting. He used concentrated solution of sodium silicate and calcium chloride as electrolyte. According to him, the chemical must be able to modify the properties of soil as desired or expected.

Question: 9. The ________ can be adopted as an aid in construction to stop rock movements and to increase the permeability of the strata as in the case of oil wells.
Explanation: Explanation: As the chemical grouting has been developed recently, the precise information of its long-term after effects is not available. Hence it has yet not become an established technique as the conventional grouting.

Question: 10. The _______ can be effectively adopted for excavation in or at the foot of the slope of a hill.
Explanation: Explanation: The freezing is a powerful versatile tool for the foundation engineering for temporary ground support, groundwater control and structural underpinning. A portion of slope is frozen and this position act as a temporary Dam to support the soil and it prevents the earth slides.

Question: 1. __________ have been developed for determining the load bearing capacity of piles.
Explanation: Explanation: Empirical formulas are based on tests which are carried out under limited conditions and hence such formulas are not generally adopted.

Question: 2. The ___________ is based upon the longitudinal wave transmission and end impact.
Explanation: Explanation: The wave action theory is too complex to be used for ordinary cases and it can be applied only after preparation of charts with the help of electronic computers.

Question: 3. The __________ equate the soil resistance to the bearing power of the pile.
Explanation: Explanation: To determine Static formulas, the samples of soils through which piles are to be driven are tested in the laboratory and properties of different soils are studied in detail. These results from the laboratory tests are then used to determine the bearing capacity of a pile of a given length, shape and size.

Question: 4. The ___________ obtain the bearing power of the piles by equating the soil resistance to the energy of the blow.
Explanation: Explanation: Extreme care should be taken while adopting dynamic formulas. There is no dynamic formula which can be applied for all the varying conditions of the work. Most of the dynamic formulas are based on some rational approach.

Question: 5. Identify the given pile driving formula.
